that's an acronym for fast meaning the unitest should run in like milliseconds
uh or less uh not multiple seconds it should be isolated meaning it should only kind of talk to itself so if you
have a method uh in C you shouldn't be communicating with like other classes and other methods and things like that
you should kind of be targeting uh that method by itself it's repeatable so if
you run it a million times you get the same result uh every single time and you shouldn't have any sort of flakiness

things uh self validating meaning it should contain its own assertions and should be able to like say like hey I

write the tests first and we'll talk about what that means a little bit later you might hear some people also

kind of talk to talk about the logic that is in uh their method itself um so
you I really like this term solitary meaning like hey uh I only communicate with myself because some people will
classify unit test more as um oh it's it only talks to things in memory like it
doesn't talk to a database or things like that which means it could communicate across multiple other classes I don't really like that
definition I think that's more of an integration test so what an integration
test is is it just invokes different part parts of a system together so it could be multiple classes communicating
with each other um a lot of people think integration tests always means uh
talking to a database talking to the file system talking to an API getting some sort of IO involved um I don't
really use that definition I prefer this definition where like it's just communicating with multiple things it could be a database it could be an API
it could be the file system but it doesn't have to be so it might have external dependencies uh like I
mentioned and um it's us usually less deterministic if you don't have what's
called a controlled dependency so if you have an uncontrolled dependency meaning you're calling out to an API that you
don't own then you might have some flakiness where if you run it a million times it might fail sometimes because
that API goes down so uh that is a trade-off with some integration tests is if you don't have a control dependency
and if you're like let's say you're using like a shared database and you're not using like a Docker database that you can just spin up locally um then
these types of tests might not be as deterministic it's also really useful
for testing Legacy code uh so if you ever deal with things like oh uh the system's like really hard to change and
things like that what I like to do for things like uh for situations like that where I'm dealing with Legacy code is I
like to write some characterization tests around the system and say like hey uh when I pass in this input I get back
this output like I don't really care what how it does its thing I just care that when I pass in you know this data
to this API that I get back this response or maybe I'm even inspecting the database like hey when I do this thing then the
database should look in this way um and I don't really care what happens in between so that way once I get those
characterization tests in place then I can start refactoring to my heart's content and start changing a lot of
things so similar to how uh there's also the term so solitary for unit test uh
there's also this term sociable for integration test which means it's communicating it's socializing with other parts of of the system and isn't
just kind of solitary by itself and I really like that word to describe integration
tests so for end to end tests uh really this is just a type of integration test
like how many people have done anything with like selenium Cyprus playwright any of those types of things okay probably a
third of the room or so cool so that is a type of end to end test and really
what an end to end test is is it invokes the system from like its entry point all the way to its end so if you have a web
app that's where a tool like Cyprus selenium playright any of those start to come into play where you're actually
interacting with a browser uh but an end to end test let's say you just have an API and that's what you deliver um you
could have an end to end test that doesn't actually interact with a browser because your entry point is the API
right but most people think of browser tests when they hear end end um this will have external dependencies so if
it's a browser test for instance like at minimum you're spinning up an actual browser uh and so you will have some
sort of external dependencies at minimum there and it won't be all in memory because again you're spinning up that
extra process to uh spin up the browser uh even if it's a headless browser you're still spinning up another
process and usually this is the slowest form of integration test um so usually
spinning up an actual browser and interacting with things usually takes a lot longer than you know just spinning up a class in memory and test testing
that class um so that is a tradeoff of end to end tests and and it's even less
deterministic typically speaking than uh than integration tests uh if you don't
have uncontrolled dependencies or I've seen a lot of people like put weights in their system where it's like hey wait for this element to show up or they just
like thread. sleep things which you should never do um just to wait for things to show up so it can even be less
deterministic than uh your typical integration test so then the question is okay how
many how many do I create of each and the answer is and anybody any

of it depends but you have to kind of ask yourself like uh what does it depend
on so there's a few different testing strategies out there so one is called the testing pyramid which the idea
behind the testing pyramid is you have a lot of unit tests kind of at the bottom level of your pyramid and so those are
really fast and really cheap to create um the side of unit tests is they
sometimes don't give you the most confidence that your system actually works so you get this nice little trade-off of like hey they run fast
they're really easy to make but they don't always give you the most confidence and as you kind of move up the pyramid uh if you follow the testing
pyramid scheme you have less integration tests than you do unit tests and integration tests start to get a little
bit slower uh a little bit costlier to maintain because you might have to set up like some database uh database data
for instance or things like that um but at the tradeoff of you get more
confidence when those things succeed and then obviously endn tests or in this case it says UI tests at the top where
those are the slowest they're the hardest hardest create but they're also give you the most confidence so it's
kind of the testing pyramid is one Paradigm around how many do you create of each so the answer is really it
depends because there's also a strategy called the testing Diamond which you can kind of see here where it's you have
less unit tests more integration tests in the middle and then less UI and end end test so this is another strategy uh
as well and I would say typically on front end code I kind of lean the testing Diamond uh way and I'm backend
code it kind of depends sometimes I'm more pyramid sometimes I'm more Diamond uh just kind of uh depends on the
situation we'll talk about that a little bit later so these are kind of different strategies you might have also heard of
like the testing trophy that's also popular in the front end space um really these are just kind of ideas about how

how multiple parts of your application integrate together so that's how I Define it but like I said lots of other
people have different opinions uh my opinion is just uh if you're integrating multiple parts of your system to me
that's still an integration test whether not you're hitting external dependencies is kind of another whole another thing
so cool all right so let's talk about test driven development uh so what is
tdd where did it come from uh so back in 2000 this guy named Kent Beck uh created
this book tdd by example and uh Kent Beck was part of a
team uh I think at Chrysler who was working on a a particular uh project I
think it was like a payroll system and he was starting to do some more extreme Pro programming practices that they that
those uh guys kind of came up with and one of those practices was test D and development so Kent ended up writing
this book to uh talk about tdd and I still think this is one of the best books about about tdd uh the examples
are in Java uh so even though I'm a c person uh it's not ideal for me but I
think it's uh I mean c and Java are close enough that's pretty pretty similar and I think this the concepts
from this book are pretty Timeless so that's kind of where tdd started getting its kickoff was when this book got
released in 2000 uh to talk about what test development is and how to practice
it so if you're interested I would still pick up that book today I still think it's worth uh worth a
read so what is tdd so it is a methodology for writing code not tests
so a lot of people think that test driven development is really about the tests and while they are useful to me
that's not the most important about part about tdd and we'll talk about that uh in more depth a little bit later so the
idea behind tdd is you write the test before you actually write your production code which can be kind of
trippy for some people of like how do I write the test before I actually write
uh the real code that I'm going to write like how do I even know what to test we'll talk about that uh a little bit
later but essentially that's that's a big part of what TD is and we'll talk about the different steps uh here in a second but essentially a big part of TD
is just you write the test before you write the production code so how do add tdd um so a lot of
people think uh how many people have heard the term Red Green green refactor okay maybe 10% of the room so a
lot of people uh think that tdd starts with writing the failing test but I
actually like this concept that first you think and think about what you're trying to do like what Behavior are you
trying to get out of your system um what like failure States could happen to this behavior um like what's all involved
like what should you be testing how should you be setting this up um so I think that's that's a key aspect is you
need to think about what you're doing before you actually start writing uh the next test then after you decide okay I
decide what test I'm going to write uh then you decide okay I'm going to write a test that describes what Behavior I
want to see out of uh the system that I'm about to create so uh that's kind of
where you uh initially write the test before you actually write the production code and then you run the test to make
sure it fails for the right reason because you haven't actually written the real implementation production code yet
so so therefore your test should pass when you go to run it now some people uh like I know Uncle Bob uh from clean code
will say a compilation failure is sufficient for red and to me that's not
sufficient for red because I want to actually see that my test fails for the right reason because I could totally set
up my test and it passes uh when everything compiles because you know I might have set up a mock that uh the way
I set it up causes that test to never even fail in the first place so I actually want to see the code compile
and fail for the right reason I'll show you a live demo of this uh here in a little bit and then you write the code
to make it pass so some people will say you should write the minimum code to make it pass uh and definitely there are
times where I do that uh but there are also times where I don't write the absolute minimum code to make it pass uh
so it uh kind of depends but if you're just starting out I would write the minimum code uh to make the test pass
and then run the test to see it pass and then after you have that uh confidence that hey my system used to
not do this thing and now it does do this thing because you ran it first it fails to prove that like hey my system
doesn't have this Behavior yet and now you've made the test pass to prove okay it does have this Behavior now now
you've got a refactor opportunity where you can say like hey I'm going to make changes to how I did this implementation that way um you know I've got that
coverage to know like hey I've got a test that covers me so if I change how things work and I break it uh my test is
going to fail and catch any problem that I might have and then you kind of repeat this cycle over and over and over again
for the next piece of behavior that you're about to write so it kind of looks something like this if you're more
of a visual person where first you think uh and then you write the failing test and then you make that test pass and
then you go under this refactor mode until you're satisfied with how the code looks and then you go back through this
think cycle again uh so this is where the term red green refactor comes from
is because first you start with the red phase of writing a failing test then you make it past and make it green and then
you start refactoring and you kind of get in this cycle of repeating this over and over and over again for the extent
of your feature so I really like this quote by
Eric Evans uh he said if you haven't seen a test fail you don't know if it
actually works so how many people have ever seen a test not test what the
original thing it was intending to test okay probably half the room yep so
that's a big thing with d d is if you don't actually see a failing red test you don't know that what you just did
targets the behavior that you're trying to capture with that test and I've even seen people like set up a mock and then
like test the mock directly which doesn't really do anything either um so that's a key part of tdd is if you don't
ever see a test fail you don't know if what you did was actually targeting what
you're uh intending to Target so what is not tdd because a lot
of people might use the term tdd when they probably didn't mean to so the first thing is tdd is not a synonym for
writing test so if somebody says hey I write write tests that doesn't necessarily that they're me meaning
they're doing tdd even though they might say they're doing TD uh if they're not writing the test first then they're not
doing tdd by definition and tdd is not writing a bunch of tests all up front before you
write any production code whatsoever so some people will say like oh I do tdd write you know all my test cases before
I write any code and that's pretty close but really tddd is about getting in that cycle where you're just focus on one
single test and making that single test pass and then kind of repeating that cycle over and over and over
again and some people will be like oh I do tdd that means I never will have bugs ever again right and that's also not the
case uh just because you have tests and you write and you do TD does not mean that you'll never have bugs so sometimes
manager need to be educated that like hey just because we have tests doesn't mean we're going to catch all of our scenarios like we might not think
through a situation or something like that and so if we never actually write the test covering that situation then
we're not actually going to be able to cover that scenario as well as uh like let's say
you've got a existing production code uh around a system right and you were like oh I want to write tests around this so
I'm going to tdd this like by definition you can't really tdd it because the existing production code already exists
right so what you could do is you could write some tests around that system like those characterization tests I was
talking about and then you could like if you want you could like remove those lines and then run the test to see it fail afterwards um so that would
indicate that hey I'm targeting what I'm intending to Target and then you can put that code back afterwards so that's kind
of close-ish to tdd but still not exactly because again that production code already exists however uh I guess a
point on that too is some people will say like oh I can't do test driven development because I've got this leg
Legacy system and that is absolutely not true so what you can do is you can take
the behavior that you're adding to your system and like rip it out into a new class or a new method and test that
method in isolation and then kind of drop it into the piece uh to the place in your legacy system where it exists so
if you start doing this methodology over time you'll get more and more tests around that Legacy system as opposed to
like oh this you know this class is 5,000 lines long what's another 10 lines
amongst friends right but the problem is that's how all of that got started right it used to be a thousand lines and then 2,000 lines and then now it's 5,000
lines so if you start ripping that behavior out into separate methods or classes um then you'll start slowly
extracting out some of that functionality and start to make your system better uh over
time uh the other thing is uh there is some testerone development uh zealots

get from people a lot is what should I be testing exactly so the number one
thing I would say is test the behavior of what you're trying to do so um I used
to be somebody who used mocks pretty heavily and I still definitely use mock um but I'm using them a lot less un less
these days because I'm more focused on like what's the behavior of my actual system versus like hey do do I want to

those tests as much as possible now but like a litmus test you could ask yourself is can you delete production
code from your application and does a test that breaks your app and does a test break if the answer is yes you're
probably missing a test and so I like to think about this a lot of like hey if I
just delete a logger statement like if I'm using I logger and C for instance and I just delete a logger statement
does that break my application probably not so usually I don't test like hey did I use the logger
correctly or things like that unless I was building something where like the logger was very instrumental to what I was doing so I might not write a test
around like hey am I using the logger correctly but if I can delete code that like breaks my like uh you know order
function place order functionality and no test breaks then there's probably a test that I'm missing and I probably
want to add uh a test there so I would say this is probably like one of the key takeaways of this talk is if is your
limit test should kind of be if you can delete production code from your app that breaks uh your app but no test
breaks then you're probably missing a test unless for some reason like the cost of creating and maintaining that
test exceeds the value of the app breaking but I found too that that might be an opportunity to refactor the code
depending on what it's doing um but yeah this is a key takeaway out of here is like if you can delete code that breaks
your app and no test breaks there's probably a problem but the opposite is also true is if your tests are broken
but your app isn't uh something also is kind of a miss so do you have like a
flaky test where you know I was calling out to an API but the API went down or
or I was talking to a shared database that were using some magic magic IDs that assumed to be in the database but
you know those got deleted by somebody for instance or um you know maybe maybe

uh as well so there's a few different forms of TD so there's what's called bottom up uh tdd or Detroit but I like
the word bottom up uh we'll talk a about that in a second and then there's also topown or London or acceptance test room
development uh is another form as well so so what bottom up is is basically you
build the bottommost layers of your application first so what this means is in fair warning this is a trigger
warning to some people because some people don't like repositories uh if you've ever been following some of that
uh craziness on Twitter uh but what this means is like you would start with like your database layer so like your
repository first maybe test that in isolation and then slowly build your work your way up to like a service or
Handler depending on whatever your application's architecture is and then eventually move up to the controller and
then uh also then like you know at the end probably add an integration test for some happy paths and things like that as
well so what I found is it's a lot easier to teach people bottom up uh than
it is to teach somebody top down test driv development because usually in top down there's a lot more moving pieces
going on and bottom up you're kind of stitching together like oh okay I just created a repository now I'm usually
have a service or a Handler that talks to the repository so then you kind of like incrementally work your way up up
and you kind of know uh the different pieces that you've already created versus top down kind of takes the
opposite approach of that where basically you start with some sort of failing integration or acceptance test
and then you start with a controller and kind of test test that in isolation and
then usually like you're like oh this controller talks to a service so I'm going to go ahead and mock out the service and test that in isolation or
you know a Handler whatever you're doing and then you know that usually talks to repository so then I'm going to go ahead
and mock that out and so typically with top down things are pretty mock heavy um
so that can be a downside of top down as you're kind of starting with uh the topmost and then kind of working your
way down so these are kind of two different approaches for uh handling testerone
development so neither style is correct and actually kind of mix and match the
two um so just pick the style that makes sense for you some people resonate with top down like I know some people who
I've worked with uh really like top down and some people people really like bottom up it just kind of depends on
what style makes sense for you so I usually mix these so I usually start with like an a failing failing acceptance test and then kind of do
bottom up from there so I kind of do a mix of top down and bottom up um but uh
the reason for that is because I think having a failing acceptance test kind of uh targets me on like the user's
behavior and then I work my way up from there and bottom up just kind of resonates with me and makes a lot more
sense uh to me but sometimes I will delete the tests after I'm done uh at
the end if I don't think that they're useful to keep around so let's say I've got an acceptance test and then uh you
know there's only a happy path for that acceptance test like there's no sad paths uh the like Intermediate Unit
